title: What are some cooking tips or hacks? - Quora

response.answer_text: Here is a glossary of food prep and cooking methods that you may find helpful :) FOOD PREP TECHNIQUES Beating – What you do to eggs before you cook them scrambled  Chopping – Cutting food into small, equal sized pieces  Creaming – Softening butter into a smooth substance and then mixing it with other ingredients  Crimping – Pressing or pinching into small folds or ridges like is done with pie crust  Deboning – Taking the bones out of meat  De-seeding – Taking seeds out of fruits and vegetables  Dicing – Chopping into tiny squares  Filleting – Slicing thin like is done with fish  Glazing – Pouring sauce on meat or other foods to add flavor and a glaze to it  Grating – Using a grater to chop down veggies  Measuring dry ingredients – Using measuring cups or spoons to measure dry ingredients like flour or sugar  Measuring liquid ingredients – Using special measuring cups for liquids to measure liquid ingredients  Mincing – Chopping into teeny tiny pieces, typically done for ginger, garlic, and chilies  Peeling – Removing the skin from vegetables  Rinsing – Washing and rubbing vegetables under cold running water to remove dirt and germs  Rolling – Using a rolling pin to flatten dough  Shredding – Like grating vegetables but into bigger, longer pieces  Skinning – Removing the skin from meat  Slicing – Cutting with a knife into thin slices  Tenderizing – Pounding meat with a hammer to break down the muscle and make it tender (so it cooks faster)  Trimming – Removing any inedible or damaged parts of food before using it  Zesting – Grating the skin of vegetables like lemons or oranges (generally citrus fruits)  COOKING METHODS Dry heat cooking Dry heat cooking involves cooking something in an oven or over an open flame. It uses hot air to conduct heat, typically at 300°F or higher. This method of cooking browns the exterior of food adding delicious flavor (think crispy chicken skin and crusty bread). Methods of dry heat cooking include: Baking – Dry cooking foods that initially lack structure, then become solid during cooking (think cakes and muffins) Roasting – Dry cooking foods that already have a solid structure before the cooking begins (think meat and vegetables) Barbecuing – Cooking meat, fish, or other food outdoors on a rack over an open fire at low temperatures for a long timeGrilling – Similar to barbecuing, it’s cooking food on a rack over an open fire, or on a grill pan, but at high temperatures for a short period of timeBroiling – Grilling is called broiling when the heat source comes from aboveRotisserie – Roasting where meat is skewered and rotated over an open flame or in an ovenSearing – Cooking the surface of food at high temperatures until a browned crust formsMoist heat cooking Moist heat cooking involves cooking with moisture – whether it’s steam, water, stock, wine, or other liquid. Compared to dry heat cooking, moist heat cooking is done at much lower temperatures, anywhere from 140°F to a maximum of 212°F, because water doesn’t get any hotter than that. Methods of moist heat cooking include: Boiling – Cooking with liquids around their boiling point Boiling – Cooking food in boiling liquidBlanching – Scalding food (usually fruits or vegetables) in boiling water, removing it after a brief time, then plunging it into ice water to halt the cooking processPoaching – Submerging food in warm liquid, such as water, milk, stock, or wine. It’s different from other moist heating techniques in that it uses relatively low temperature.Pressure cooking – Cooking food in a pressure cooker using water or other liquid. It simulates the effects of long braising in shorter time.Simmering– Heating food in water kept just below the boiling pointSteaming – Cooking food using the steam from boiling waterSteeping – Soaking solid food in liquid to extract flavors or soften itStewing – Cooking solid food in liquid and serving the resulting gravyFrying – Cooking food in oil or other fat Deep frying – Cooking food by completely submerging it in hot oil or fatPan frying – Frying on a pan with just enough oil to coat the panSautéing – Pan frying food (that is cut into smaller pieces) quickly and at higher temperaturesOther techniques Basting – Cooking meat either in its own juices or in a sauce or marinade. The meat is left to cook, then periodically coated with the juice.Braising – A combination of both dry and wet cooking: the food is first seared at high temperatures, then finished in a covered pot at lower temperatures in liquidSmoking – Flavoring, browning, or cooking food by exposing it to smoke from burning or smoldering material, most often wood

Poaching eggs: Put a mason jar lid at the bottom of the pot, deposit egg into it. Making pastry: Freeze butter, then grate. Large pieces for brisee, small ones for choux. Proofing dough: Always use a wet towel instead of plastic wrap. Yeast acts more quickly in a humid environment.  Always place a baking stone at the bottom of your oven, even if you're not using it. It draws hot air and helps keep the temperature stable even if you open the oven door.  Bread: Always test your yeast before you use it by mixing it in a solution of 3 parts warm water, one part sugar. One teaspoon of yeast to about 250 ml of solution should yield a bowl covered in thick foam after five minutes. If this isn't happening, your yeast is not optimal. Deglazing: Use beer diluted with club soda or weak lemon juice. This prevents the taste of the solvent from overpowering the fond. Alternately, use XO sauce diluted with water (this is what I do). Chocolate: Use a double boiler and candy thermometer. Microwaving or melting over direct heat can easily result in the chocolate seizing. Sauteing: Avoid using butter; it will burn at the temperatures required for a proper saute. If you must have the flavor of butter, clarify it first. Deep-frying: Safflower oil. Results in the cleanest and lightest and taste and the oil does not overpower the flavor of whatever it is you're deep frying. Cookies: Refrigerate dough for a night, preferably two. This allows flavor to develop more, resulting in a richer taste. Sauteing again: Heat the pan to desired temperature, THEN add oil. This prevents loose particles in the oil from burning and affecting the taste. Also, for a typical saute pan or skillet, use only 1-2 tablespoons fat to saute (enough to simply grease the pan without any pooling at the bottom. This helps develop fond. Bread again: When a recipe calls for hot or warm water to be added to a sifted mixture of flour, make sure it is no hotter than 50 degrees C and no cooler than 40 degrees C. This range is optimal because warmer water will aid in the development of gluten without reaching the temperature at which yeast dies. Pan sauces: When making pan sauces from vegetable fond, add a bit of mustard seed to aid in thickening. Fond produced from vegetables has little protein and will not thicken unless either starch or mustard seed are added. Mustard seed is better because starch dampens flavor too much. Burgers: Make sure your cut of beef is no more than 85% lean. If your meat appears too lean, add unclarified, raw pork fat (NOT lard). Spread the meat on a surface and pat it dry first. Then,mix your meat with a bit of egg and bread as well. These two things keep the burger from falling apart on the grill or expanding too much from steam as it cooks.  Fries: Let potatoes sit in cool water for about half an hour, or quickly blanche them before frying. This removes starch and helps keep the fries crispier for longer. Make sure you accurately measure temp when making fries. Optimal oil temp should be around 190 degrees C. Any lower and the fries will absorb too much oil, making them soggy and nasty. If you lack a deep fryer, use a thick bottomed pan to prevent temperature from dropping too much as you deposit potatoes into the oil.
